editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SONGS OF THE OLD AND NEW TESTAMENT IN MEETER:
By M. ZACHARY BOYD Preacher of Gods Word.
div.q: Be ye filled with the Spirit, &c.
Speaking to your selves in Psalmes, and Hymnes, and spirituall Songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord.
div.p: GLASGOW, Printed by the Heires of GEORGE ANDERSON. Anno 1648.

div.head: The Songs of the Old and New Testament.

list.item: The Song of Moses at the red Sea. 2.
The song of Moses a little before his death 3
Davids lamentations for: Saul and Ionathan. 6
The song of David at the promise of Messias. 7
The song of Isaiah concerning the vineyard. 8
Isaiahs song of thanks for Gods mercies. 9
Isaiahs song inciting to confidence in God. 10

div.head: To the right Reverend, the faithfull Ministers of GODS Word of the Church of Scotland.
div.p:
IT pleased You in the Generall Assembly last, at Edinburgh, Anno 1647. to take to your consideration, the great utility the Church of GOD may have by the Songs contained in holy Scriptures; After due deliberation, it pleased You to ordain that I should labour in that work • In obedience unto You, I have endeavoured to come as neer to the Text as was possible for me to do; And those my labours I in all humility
offer to be considered, by the most learned and most judicious Brethren, that the Church having the use thereof, may in obedience to the Apostles precept Ephes. 5. 18. in Psalmes, and Hymnes, and spirituall Songs, make melody in their heart to the Lord, whom I intreat in all humility to direct You in all things by his holy Spirit; So I remain

closer.signed: Your humble servant in the LORD, M. ZACHARY BOYD.

div.head: THE SONG OF Solomon made in praise of Christ, and his Church.
CHAPTER I.
div.p: LEt him kisse me with the kisses of his mouth, for thy love is better then wine.

lg.l: LEt him with kisses of his mouth
For sure thy love farre better is

div.p: 2 Because of the savour of thy good oyntments, thy name is as oyntment powred forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.

lg.l: Because that of thine ointments • ood
Thy Name as ointment forth is powr'd

div.p: 3 Draw me, we will run after thee: the King hath brought me into his chambers:

lg.l: Do thou me draw and then anone
The King himself he hath me now

div.p: We will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more then wine: the upright love thee.

lg.l: We'l in thee glade be and rejoice,

div.p: 4 I am black, but comely, (O ye daughters of Ierusalem) as the tents of Kedar, as the curtains of Solomon.

lg.l: O Salems daughters black I am,
As tents of Kedar, and ev'n as

div.p: 5 Look not upon me because I am black, because the Sun hath looked upon me.

lg.l: Upon me look not ye, because
I black do seem to be,
Because the Sun hath with his beames

div.p: My mothers children were angry with mee, they made me the keeper of the vineyards, but mine own vineyard have I not kept.

lg.l: My mothers children wroth with me
But I my self have not at all

div.p: 6 Tell me (O thou whom my soul loveth) where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon:

lg.l: O thou, whom dearly loves my soul,
I pray thee tell me soon
Where thou dost feed, and where thou makst
thy flock to rest at noon.

div.p: For why should I be as one that turneth aside by the flocks of thy companions?

lg.l: For why should I be any way

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 7 If thou know not, (O thou fairest among women) go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds tents.

lg.l: O fairest one if thou not know,
And do thou feed thy kids beside

sp.p: 8 I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaohs chariots.
9 Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.
10 We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.

lg.l: With jewell rows thy cheeks are fair,
with chaines of gold thy neck:
Of gold we borders will thee make

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 11 While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.
12 A bundle of myrrhe is my welbeloved unto me;

lg.l: While at his table sits the King
Of mirrhe a bundle unto me

sp.p: He shall ly all night betwixt my breasts.
13 My beloved is unto me, as a cluster of Camphire, in the vineyards of Engedi.

lg.l: Betwixt my breasts hee'le lie all night

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 14 Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair, thou hast doves eyes.

lg.l: O do behold, most fair thou art
ev'n thou my love so rare,
Behold of Doves the eyes thou hast,

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 15 Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea pleasant: also our bed is green.
16 The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fire.

lg.l: Lo, pleasant fair thou art my love,
Beams of our house they cedars are,

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: I Am the rose of Sharon, and the lilly of the valleyes.
2 As the lilly among thornes, so is my love among the daughters.

lg.l: I'M Sharons rose, the lilly als
As lillies among thornes, my love

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 3 As the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons.

lg.l: As th • apple tree among the trees
is of the wood so throng,

sp.p: • I sate down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.

lg.l: Under his shadow I sate down
And there his fruit which pleasant is

sp.p: 4 He brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.

lg.l: to come he did me move▪
His banner that was over me

sp.p: 5 Stay me with flagons, comfort me with apples; for I am sick of love.
6 His left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.

lg.l: Me sick of love with flagons stay,
Under my head his left hand is,

sp.p: 7 I charge you, O ye daughters of Ierusalem, by the Roes, and by the Hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love till he please.

lg.l: By Roes, field Hindes, O Salems maids,
I charge you that ye cease
• o stir or yet at all awake

sp.p:
8 The voice of my beloved! behold, he co
• eth leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon
•• e hils.

lg.l: The voice of my Belov'd! behold!

sp.p:
9 My beloved is like a roe, or a young hart: hold, he standeth behinde our wall, he looketh
•• th at the windows, shewing himself through
•• e lattesse.

lg.l: He's like a Roe or Hart that's young,
• t windowes he looks forth, himself

sp.p:
10 My beloved spake, and said unto me,
• se up my love, my faire one, and come away.

11 For lo, the winter is past, the raine is over
•• d gone.

lg.l: Then my Belov'd said, Rise my love,
For lo the winter it is past,
the rain is ov'r and gone.

sp.p:
12 The flowers appear on the earth, the time
• he singing of birds is come, and the voice of turtle is heard in our land.

lg.l: The flowers upon the earth appear,
The time is come; the Turtles voice

sp.p: 13 The fig-tree putteth forth her green figs and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell. Arise, my love, my faire one, and come away.

lg.l: The fig tree her green figs puts forth,
Do sweetly smell; arise my love

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 14 O my dove that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs,

lg.l: O thou my dove that art ev'n now
the staires where thou dost lurk.

sp.p: Let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice, for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.

lg.l: Let thou me see thy countenance,
thy voice let thou me hear,
For sweet thy voice is, and also

sp.p: 15 Take us the Foxes, the little foxes that spoile the vines: for our vines have tender grapes.

lg.l: Do ye for us the foxes take,
That spoile the vines, for tender grapes
our vines have, as ye see.

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p:
16 My beloved is mine, and I am his: he
• eedeth among the lillies.

17 Vntill the day break, and the shadowes
• lee away: turn my beloved, and be thou like a Roe, or a young Hart, upon the mountains of Bether.

lg.l: Untill day break and shads flee hence,
Thou like a Roe, or Hart that's young

div.head: CHAPTER III.
div.p:
BY night on my bed I sought him whom my soul loveth: I sought him, but I found
• im not.

lg.l: BY night I did upon my bed
him seek with all my minde
VVhom my soul loveth; I him sought,
but him I did not find.

div.p: 2 I will rise now, and go about the citie in the streets, and in the broad wayes I will seek him whom my Soul loveth:

lg.l: I will now rise, and in the streets
And in the broad wayes I will seek
him whom my soul doth love.

div.p: I sought him, but I found him not.
3 The watchmen that goe about the city found mee: to whom I said, Saw ye him whom my Soul loveth.
div.l: I sought him, but I found him not,

lg.l: Did find; I said then did ye him

div.p: 4 It was but a little that I passed from them, but I found him whom my Soul loveth;

lg.l: It but a little was that I
But I him whom my soul doth love

div.p: I held him, and would not let him goe, untill I had brought him into my mothers house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.

lg.l: I held and would not let him go,
Was to her house and chamber brought

div.p: 5 I charge you, O ye daughters of Ierusalem, by the Roes, and by the Hindes of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love till hee please.

lg.l: O Salems daughters I you charge
by Roes, field Hindes ye cease
To stir or yet for to awake

div.p: 6 Who is this that cometh out of the wildernesse like pillars of smoake, perfumed with myrrhe and frankincense, with all powders of the merchant.

lg.l: Of smoak like pillars who is this

div.p: 7 Behold his bed, which is Solomons: threescore valiant men are about it, of the valiant of Israel.

lg.l: About it are, of those that are

div.p: 8 They all hold swords, being expert in war, Every man hath his sword upon his thigh, because of fear in the night.

lg.l: Expert in war, they all do hold
swords in their hands most bright,
• ach man his sword hath on his thigh,

div.p: 9 King Solomon made himself a charet of the wood of Lebanon.
10 He made the pillars thereof of silver, the bottom thereof of gold,

lg.l: It's pillars made of silver were,

div.p: The covering of it of purple, the midst thereof being paved with love, for the daughters of Ierusalem.

lg.l: The cov'ring of it purple was,
the midst of it for them
Was pav'd with love, that daughters were

div.p: 11 Go forth, O ye daughters of Zion, and behold King Solomon,

lg.l: And do ye with great reverence

div.p: With the crown wherewith his mother crowned him in the day of his espousals, and in the day of the gladnesse of his heart.

lg.l: With crown wherewith his mother him
And in the day his heart was fill'd

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: BEhold, thou art faire, my love, behold thou art faire, thou hast doves eyes within thy locks:

lg.l: BEhold my love thou art most fair▪
The pure and chast eyes of the Dove

sp.p:
Thy haire is as a flock of goats, that appear •
from mount Gilead.

lg.l: Thy haire that is upon thy head,
Like to a flock of goats that from

sp.p: 2 Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep, that are even shorn which came up from the washing, whereof every one beare twins, and none is barren among them.

lg.l: Thy teeth are like a flock of sheep,
Whereof each one bare twins, and them

sp.p: 3 Thy lips are like a threed of scarlet, and thy speach is comely: thy temples are like a prece of a pomegranate within thy locks.

lg.l: Thy speach is comely, and thy lips
Within thy locks thy temples like

sp.p: 4 Thy neck is like the tower of David, buil • ded for an armory, whereon there hang a thou • sand bucklers, all shields of mighty men.

lg.l: Thy neck is like King Davids tower,

sp.p:
5 Thy two breasts are like two young Roe •

lg.l: Thy breasts in number two are like

sp.p: 6 Vntill the day break, and the shadows flee away, I will get me to the mo • ntaine of myrrhe, and to the hill of frankincense.

lg.l: Untill the day most clearly break

sp.p: 7 Thou art all fair, my love, there is no spot in thee.
8 Come with me from Lebanon, my spouse, with me from Lebanon:

lg.l: Thou art all fair my love, there is
no spot at all in thee:
Spouse come with me from Lebanon

sp.p: Look from the top of Amana, from the top of Shenir and Hermon, from the Lyons dens, from the mountains of the Leopards.

lg.l: Look from the tops of Amana,
From Lions dens, from mountaines great

lg.l: My heart thou ravish'd, sister, spouse,
Hast ravish'd with one of thine eyes,
with one chain of thy neck.

sp.p: 10 How fair is thy love, my sister, my spouse, how much better is thy love then wine? and the smell of thine oyntments then all spices.

lg.l: How fair's thy love, my sister spouse?
Is this thy love! thine ointments smell

sp.p:
11 Thy lips, O my spouse drop as the hon
comb, hony and milk are under thy tongue, and the smell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.

lg.l: Thy lips, Spouse, drop as hony comb,

sp.p: 12 A garden inclosed is my sister, my spouse: a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.

lg.l: My sister spouse a garden is,
A spring shut up, a fountain als

sp.p: 13 Thy plants are an orchard of Pomegranates, with pleasant fruits, Camphire, with Spikenard.

lg.l: A fountain for to water well
A well of living waters als

div.head: CHAPTER V.

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: I Am come into my garden, my sister, my spouse, I have gathered my Myrrhe with my spice,

lg.l: MY sister and my spouse, I am

sp.p: I have eaten my hony comb with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk: eat, O friends, drink, yea drink abundantly, O beloved!

lg.l: I hony comb with hony ate,
my wine, milk, drunk have I,
Eat, O ye friends, drink O Belov'd;

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 2 I sleep, but mine heart waketh: it is the voice of my beloved that knocketh, saying,

lg.l: I sleep securely but my heart
doth wake both night and day,
It is the voice of my Belov'd

sp.p: Open to me, my sister, my love, my dove, my undefiled: for my head is filled with dew, and my locks with the drops of the night.

lg.l: For filled is my head with dew,
my locks with drops of night.

sp.p: 3 I have put off my coat, how shall I put it on? I have washed my feet, how shall I defile them?

lg.l: I have put off my coat, how shall
I put it on a while?
I washed also have my feet

sp.p: 4 My beloved put in his hand by the hole o the door, and my bowels were moved for him.

lg.l: By of the door the hole his hand
And for him then my bowels all

sp.p:
5 I rose up to open to my beloved, and my hands dropped with Myrrhe, and my fingers with sweet smelling Myrrhe, upon the handles o •
the lock.

lg.l: To open to my love I rose,
my hands with myrrhe did drop,
My fingers with sweet smelling myrrhe

sp.p: 6 I opened to my beloved, but my beloved had withdrawn himself, and was gone:

lg.l: To my Belov'd I op'ned then,
and from the door was gone:

sp.p: My soul failed: when he spake I sought him but I could not finde him: I called him, but he gave me no answer.

lg.l: My soul it failed when he spake,
But could not find him, I him call'd,

sp.p: 7 The watchmen that went about the citie, found me, they smote mee, they wounded me, the keepers of the walls took away my vaile from me.

lg.l: The cities watchmen found me then,
The keepers of the wals they took

sp.p: 8 I charge you, O daughters of Ierusalem, if ye finde my beloved, that ye tell him, that I am sick of love.

lg.l: If my Belov'd ye find, that yee
him tell, I'm sick of love.

div.p: 9 What is thy beloved more then another beloved, O thou fairest among women? what is thy beloved more then another beloved, that thou dost so charge us?

lg.l: What is he more then others are,
that thou dost charge so sore?

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 10 My beloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest among ten thousand.
11 His head is as the most fine gold, his looks are bushie and black as a raven.

lg.l: Both white and rudy's my Belov'd,
His head's as gold, his bushy locks
are black as is a rav'n.

sp.p: 〈◊〉 His eyes are as the eyes of doves by the rivers of waters, washed with milk and fitly set.

lg.l: His eyes are as the eyes of doves
They washed also are with milk

sp.p: 13 His cheeks are as a bed of spices, as sweet flowres: his lips like lillies, dropping sweet smelling myrrhe.

lg.l: His cheeks are as the spices bed,
His lips like lillies droping Myrrhe,

sp.p: 14 His hands are as gold rings set with the Berill: His belly is as bright ivory, overlaid with Saphires.

lg.l: His hands as goldrings als are set
His belly as bright ivory is

sp.p: 15 His legs are as pillars of marble, set upon sockets of fine gold: his countenance is as Lebanon, excellent as the Cedars.

lg.l: His legs like Marble pillars are,

sp.p: 16 His mouth is most sweet: yea, he is altogether lovely: This is my beloved, and this is my friend, O daughters of Ierusalem.

lg.l: Most sweet his mouth is, yea he is
This my Belov'd, and this my Friend

div.head: CHAPTER VI.
div.p: WHether is thy beloved gone? O thou fairest among women, whether is thy beloved turned aside? that we may seek him with thee.

lg.l: O whither turn'd, that we with thee

sp.speaker: The Church.
sp.p: 2 My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of spices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lillies.

lg.l: To feed in gardens is gone down

sp.p: 3 I am my beloveds, and my beloved is mines be feedeth among the lillies.

lg.l: Is likewise mine: and now he doth

sp.speaker: CHRIST.
sp.p: 4 Thou art beautifull, O my love as Tirzah comely as Ierusalem, terrible as an army with banners.

lg.l: Thou art; as one host terrible

sp.p: 5 Turne away thine eyes from me for they have overcome me: thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.

lg.l: From me thine eyes turn thou away,

sp.p: 6 Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep which go up from the washing, whereof every one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among them.

lg.l: Thy teeth are as a flock of sheep,
Eacl • one bears twins, and there is not

sp.p: 7 As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.

lg.l: The temples also of thine head
As of a pomegtanate a piece

sp.p: 8 There are threescore Queens, and fourescore Concubines, and Virgins without number.

lg.l: Though threescore of fair queens there be,
And virgins als them to attend,

sp.p: 9 My dove, my undefiled is but one: she is the only one of her mother, she is the choice one of her that bare her:

lg.l: My Dove my undefild's but one,
Is th'onely one, and she the choise
is of her that her bare.

sp.p: The daughters saw her, and blessed her▪ yea, the Queens and the Concubines and they praised her.

lg.l: The daughters of the land her saw,
Yea ev'n the Queens and Concubines and they als did her praise.

sp.p: 10 Who is she that looketh foorth as the morning, fair as the moon clear as the sun, and terrible as an army with banners?

lg.l: Who's she as morning that looks forth,
fair as the Moon, and clear
As is the sun, and armies as

sp.p: 11 I went down into the garden of nuts, to see the fruits of the valley, and to see whether the vine flourished, and the pomegranates budded.

lg.l: I down to the Nut-garden went
To see if vines were flouri • h'd, and

sp.p: 12 Or ever I was aware, my soul made me like the chariots of Amminadab.

lg.l: Or ever then I was aware,
my soul i • at the last
made me to make great hast.

sp.p: 13 Return, return, O Shulamite, return, return, that we may look upon thee:

lg.l: That we with gladnesse great of heart
may so now look on thee;

sp.p: What will ye see in the Shulamite? as it were the company of two armies.

lg.l: What will ye in the Shulamite
Ev'n such a sight as if it were

div.head: CHAPTER VII.
div.p:
HOw beautifull are thy feet with sho • es, O Princes daughter, the joynts of thy thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a cun
• ing work-man.

lg.l: HOw beatifull thy feet with shoes
Joints of thy thighs are jewels like

div.p: 2 Thy navell is like a round goblet, which wanteth not licour: thy belly is like an heap of wheat, set about with lillies.

lg.l: Thy navel's like a goblet round,
Thy belly's like an heap of wheat,

div.p: 3 Thy two breasts are like two young Roes, that are twins.
4 Thy neck is as a tower of ivory: thine eyes like the fish pooles in Heshbon, by the gate of Bathrabbim:

lg.l: Thy breasts are like two twin young Roes:
Thy neck, thine eyes like Heshbons pools

div.p: Thy nose is as the towre of Lebanon, which looketh toward Damascus.

lg.l: Thy nose it is ev'n like the towre
Which toward all the city of

div.p: 5 Thine head upon thee is like Carmell, and the haire of thine head like purple, the King is held in the galleries.

lg.l: Thy head on thee is Carmel like,
als of thine head the hair
Is Purple like, the King is held

div.p: 6 How faire, and how pleasant art thou, O Love, for delights!
7 This thy stature is like to a palme tree, and thy breasts to clusters of grapes.

lg.l: O love how art thou for delights
Thy stature • 's like palme trees, thy breasts

div.p: 8 I said, I will go up to the palme tree, I will take hold of the boughs thereof,

lg.l: I did then say that I go up
Yea of the boughs thereof I will
with all my force take hold.

div.p: Now also thy breasts shall be as clusters of the vine, and the smell of thy nose like apples.

div.head: The Song of Moses a little before his death. DEUT. 32.
The Preface.
div.p: GIve ear, O ye heavens, and I will speak; and hear, O earth, the words of my mouth.

The words that from my mouth proceed

lg.l: My doctrine as the rain shall drop,
my speach as dew shall passe,
As small rain on the tender herb,

div.p: 3 Because I will publish the name of the Lord: ascribe ye greatnesse unto our God.

lg.l: the Name of God the Lord,
Ye greatnesse to our God therefore

div.head: The first Part.
div.p: 4 He is the Rock, his work is perfect: for all his wayes are judgement: a God of truth, and without iniquity, just and right is he.

lg.l: He is the rock, his work's persite,
A God of truth, void of all sin,
most just and right is he.

div.p:
5 They have corrupted themselves, their spot is not the spot of his children: they are
•
perverse and crooked generation.

lg.l: Their spot is not his childrens spot,

lg.l: the Lord thus? Is not he
Thy father, buyer? Hath he not

lg.l: Remember ye the dayes of old,
Thy father ask, he will thee shew,

lg.l: For to his portion hath the Lord

lg.l: So by his might the Lord alone

div.p: 13 He made him ride on the high places of the earth, that he might eat the increase of the fields, and he made him to suck hony out of the rock, and oil out of the flinty rock.

From flinty rocks he made him suck

div.head: The second Part.
div.p: 15 But Iesurun waxed fat, and kicked: thou art waxen fat, thou art grown thick,

lg.l: With fatnesse thou art cov'rd, he then
And he of his salvations rock

to gods whom they not knew,

that were come up of new.

lg.l: And when the Lord it saw, he did

and I their end will see:
For they a very froward race,

div.p: 21 They have moved me to jealousie with that which is not God, they have provoked me to anger with their vanities:

lg.l: With that which is not God they have
To anger they have me provok'd,

lg.l: And I'le them move to jealousie

Ev'n with the poison that is of

with him whose haires are gray.

Our hand now high is, and the Lord

and their last end would weigh.

• xcept their Rock thus had them sold,

• ur enemies themselves being judges.

•• apes of gall, their clusters are bitter.

• mpence, their foot shall slide in due time:

When none shut up or left he sees
but that their power is spent.

where are their gods now gone?

lg.l: Which fat ate of their sacrifice,

lg.l: See now that I am he, ev'n I,
no god there is with me:
I kill, and make alive; I wound,
and als make whole to be.

div.p: Neither is there any that can deliver out of my hand.

For I lift up my hand to heaven,
and say, I live for ever.

lg.l: If hold my hand on judgement take,
I'le render vengeance to my foes,
and pay those that me hate.

blood (and my sword shall devour flesh)

the enemy.

div.p: 10 The Sun and Moon stood still in their habitations: at the light of thine arrows they went, and at the shining of thy glittering spear,

div.p: 15 When I heard, my belly trembled: my lips quivered at the voice: rottennes entred into my bones,

lg.l: My belly trembled when I heard.

div.p: And I trembled in my self, that I might rest in the day of trouble: when he cometh up unto the people, he will invade them with his troups.

lg.l: I trembled in my self, that I
might rest in dayes most sad,
When he up to the people comes

div.p: BLessed be the Lord God of Israel, for he hath visited and redeemed his people,

And likewise from the hand of all

div.head: Georgii Buchanani hymnus Matutinus ad Christum.

lg.l: O Day spring from on hy
Of lights thou art the Light
Thy beams they are most bright,
Through all the world they run:
Wee hope to see this Sun
And there he beames shall shake,
To make that dew to fall
The dew of grace and peace,
May bring to us our day.
A day to shine for ay,
A day that is most bright;
O of all lights the light,
The light that is most true,
Thy face now to us shew,
O Son of God most dear,
• rath due to us thou bare
And for us shed thy blood.
Like beasts they are most rude,
Who do not for thy good
To walk still in thy way
First make us sick of love,
O that we light could see.
So at the last should we
Where God's seen face to face
O that our hours were spent
